Award.AwardTitle: 2nd ASTFE/IWHT Conference and Workshop on Fluid Flow and Heat Transfer (Las Vegas, NV April 2-5, 2017)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2nd ASTFE/IWHT Conference and Workshop on Fluid Flow and Heat Transfer is the primary and most important international conference being organized by the American Society of Thermal and Fluids Engineers (ASTFE). This is the second conference being organized by the society, following the successful first conference held in New York last year. This conference is rapidly becoming the main conference in thermal transport and fluids, providing a new venue for dissemination of top research in the thermal-fluids area.

This conference also provides a forum for the open exchange of progress in the research, development, manufacturing and application of thermal-fluids engineering. Last year the conference attracted researchers and practitioners from all over the world, and from academia, industry, and government and served as a conduit for knowledge dissemination and collaboration among its participants. The conference also attempts to connect a diverse global engineering community and already has support from the International Centre of Heat and Mass Transfer (the premier international institution of the thermal transport processes community), Begell House Publishing and from the UNLV.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This conference was a continuation of the first conference held in New York in 2015. The continuing interest in meetings and conferences to discuss common problems and new approaches utilizing the latest techniques clearly underscores the importance in accurately resolving complex, real world issues involving fluid flow and heat transfer. A total of ten special lectures were given: two TFEC Plenary speakers, one TFEC keynote speaker, two IWHT Plenary speakers, and five IWHT keynote speakers during the three-day conference. A special lecture was presented by NSF on past and future thermal transport processes. In addition, six speakers presented short, 10 minute TEC talks that were recorded for eventual presentation on the web (sponsored by Begell House, Inc.). Poster sessions were held each day, with each poster session lasting 2 hours. Each plenary or keynote lecture lasted approximately 50 minutes. In addition, there were several open, informal sessions (any relevant technical issue). The conference provided an excellent opportunity for research discussions among the United States participants and the rest of the attendees. In addition, the conference provided a forum for discussions on various experimental and numerical techniques, with possible cooperative research ventures with several United States researchers. The proceedings of the conference were prepared by Begell House, Inc. Selected papers have been submitted to Computational Thermal Sciences, a journal published by Begell House.
